body.body: Collect neatly the piperidine solution \(12 mL/mg) used for deprotection \(steps 4-5 of the standard protocol) in a small flask or glass vial.
Dilute 1/20 with 20% piperidine in DMF \(in a small vial: 100 μL collected solution + 1.9 mL 20% piperidine). Mix.
Fill the UV cell with 2.7 mL of 20% piperidine in DMF \(reference solution), place the cell into the spectrophotometer and zero at λ=301 nm.
Add 300 μL of the solution prepared at step 2 into the cell, mix and measure the absorbance.

Calculate the loading using the following equation:
  Loading \(mmol/g) = Abs<sub>sample</sub> x 0.4<sup>a</sup>


abased on ε<sub>301</sub>=6000 M<sup>-1</sup>cm<sup>-1</sup> \(ε depends also on the specifications of the spectrometer\!); 3 mL deblocking solution, 1/200 dilution, 250mg resin.


Constance \(or slight progressive decrease) of loading is an indication of good progress of the synthesis. If loading values vary irregularly or decrease drastically, a microcleavage test \(described below) should be performed.
Transfer a few resin beads to a small glass tube and wash several times with ethanol.
Add 100 μL of each of the solutions above.

Mix well and place the tube in a pre-heated oven \(115 °C) for 5 min.
  ▲ CRITICAL STEP To reduce the incidence of false negative results, it is recommendable to carry out a parallel positive control. The test is not applicable to N-terminal proline residues \(secondary amine) and N-alkyl amino acids. The test may give false negative results when applied to aggregate sequences.
Transfer a sample containing ~1-2 mg dry peptide-resin to a small syringe \(2 mL).
Add 300 μL of the cleavage cocktail \[TFA/ H<sub>2</sub>O/ phenol/ TIPS 8.5/ 0.5/ 0.5/ 0.5] to the dried peptide resin, stir gently for 30 sec and wait for 3 h \(stir gently in-between).
Collect the solution in a small HPLC vial, dilute with 400 μL ACN/water 1/1, mix.
At this point the solution can be analyzed in an analytical HPLC system \(inject 20 μL) and/or further diluted \(1/10) to be injected \(2 μL) in LC-MS.
